												There should be more people playing this game online. It looks amazing, it plays really smoothly, it has a very fast paced gameplay.The player movement feels a bit strange at first, but you get used to it pretty fast. About the weapons: They are very varied and have very specific roles and situations to be used on effectively. You only get to choose 2 weapons at a time. That means you can't adapt to situations without dying, choosing a different loadout and respawning. Level design doesn't give you that many situations either. The levels are very open arenas, made to showcase the awesome gravity gameplay. It's a bit strange to just walk and use the planet you're standing on as cover. But there's enough weapon variety for people with higher pings to have a lot of fun, without having to rely solely on accuracy to get some kills.There's 2 main gametypes. The classic DeathMatch, and Orbital Warfare. The later one being the most strategic, requiring you to defend your structures while attacking the enemy base. While there is potential for tactics here, the matches tend to be very offensive. There's no tools to provide support roles (you need to kill enemies to repair structures), or to play defensively (the shield item lasts a couple of seconds and doesn't stop enemies). So you'll really need to coordinate with your teammates to create a good minefield defense, or a satellite based defense line. Otherwise, it ends up feeling like team deathmatch with some extra objectives.Placeable roadblocks, a big permanent shield item that can cover an entire structure for 30 seconds but with a 15 seconds cooldown, big mines that follow the orbit of the planet it was deployed on, or an item that teleports you back to your base, could be features that might spice up that gamemode.This is a very well crafted game. I really hope future updates bring some more maps to play on, and some sort of single player contents, for those days when we can't find online games.

												Simplicity is both a virtue and a vice in Orbital Gears, a 2.5D side-scrolling multiplayer-only shooter armed with an interesting gimmick: the gravitational fields of deep space.The virtue is that, as a giant mech, you run around planets -- quite literally, in this case -- using their gravity to zip around a solar system-sized map, hopping Orbital Gear from one world to the next and shooting opponents. The vice is that, well, that’s about all there is to it. A paltry two modes, Deathmatch and Orbital Warfare, are included. Deathmatch is self-explanatory; Orbital Warfare is a more strategic team-based affair that’s essentially King of the Hill in space.There aren’t too many surprises in level layouts, either. The six Deathmatch maps and three Orbital Warfare maps are pretty similar to one another.While there are numerous weapons to choose from, and finding ways of making them interact with the environment is enjoyable, the majority of them suffer a common flaw. They have this weird half-second delay in their initial firing - with the exception of the mini-gun, which has to spool up.The total lack of single-player content though, actually negatively impacts the multiplayer side of the equation to a fair degree.Mainly because, even a week and a half after launch, there are at most a small handful of servers available at any one time, and often none whatsoever. Without other people playing, a multiplayer online-only shooter is about as useful as a disconnected telephone.Orbital Gear can be a frantic shooter that pulls you in with its gravitational gimmickry, but lacks the forward momentum to keep me playing for long.Overall 6/10.

UPDATEThe promised single-player feature has been released - it's called Orbital Trials where you have to kill certain baddies with certain weapons as fast as you can. The faster you go, the more stars you get. You need to collect a certain amount of stars to unlock the next one.It's an interesting single-player mode, but I'd much have preferred normal Deathmatch/Orbital Warfare battles with bots instead. Still, at least there's something to do in single-player. I've increased my rating below. Original unedited review follows. ----------------------------------------------This game got onto Steam as a result of Who's Gaming Now?!'s free key for a Greenlight vote promotion. In truth, after playing this game for a while, I felt that it wasn't really needed - this game was fantastic, entertaining and it blew me away, and it could probably have gotten onto Steam by merit alone. (Though I would no doubt agree that WGN?! gave it the much-needed exposure it deserved.)Orbital Gear is a 2D space game with beautiful 3D graphics about fighting mechs (called 'Gears'). There are 12 interesting weapons with defining characteristics, 2 game modes (plain deathmatch and Orbital Warfare where teams destroy opposing team buildings) and 4 other mech utilities. A great variety of maps coupled with the weapon choices make for some interesting battles as you mix and match your gear (pun unintended) to get an optimal setup.What Orbital Gear has going for it is its rather fresh combination of 2D platform shooting and planet gravity mechanics. Flying (gliding, rather) around the planets, jumping around from here to there is a rather exhilarating and heart-racing experience. The gravity mechanics really shake up the game a lot, and are a very solid foundation to build upon. (I mean, because of all the gravity, you're firmly planted to the foundation.....never mind.)Where the game (currently) falls short in is the fact that it's for now a multiplayer-only game. Now it's no secret that on Steam most multiplayer-only games are rendered lifeless within months, because everyone will be going back to their DOTAs, their CSGOs, their TF2s, and so on and so forth. As such, during the time I spent playing, I only found a maximum of 2 open games at any point of time, some with only 1 player. Developer Night Node has promised to add a practice single player mode in future updates, but for now I'd recommend being wary of this.Despite the major lack of single player shortcomings, the rest of the game already feels quite polished and well done. I'd recommend checking this game out with a few friends if you have the time. Oh, and the electronic soundtrack is surprisingly great, too.When to buyWith the lack of people in multiplayer, unfortunately I feel it best to buy it from bundles. The single player mode is like a snack - not very filling.8.5/10This game was previously demoed on the Who's Gaming Now?! Twitch Channel[www.twitch.tv]. We regularly demo indie games on the channel, consider tossing us a follow.

												Since you are probably skimming through the reviews to make up your mind on a purchase, I’ll save you some time and summarise this game with three words, they are cheap (price tag), stylish (graphics) and fun (game play). If that wasn’t enough to convince you, read on.This title is essentially an arena game set upon a 2D platform with 3D graphics, the twist revolves around the clever implementation of gravity around structures and planets, with which the players will use to maneuver their mechs. The system can be confusing at first, but very rewarding once a player gets the hang of it, I was pulling gravitational slingshot and performing swing-by shooting within an hour.The guns themselves are fairly mundane and standard among this type of game, but the twelve of them do vary a great deal in terms of play style and tactics. There are four utility tools available as well, but I rarely see people use them to much effect in game.As for game modes, you have the basic Death Match which is self explanatory. Then you have Orbital Warfare, a territorial tug-of-war in which both teams race to charge up their main cannons for a devastating blast. Lastly you have Orbital Trials, a single player time attack mode that pits you up against patrolling machines on a map with limited weaponry; this was added by the developers after much request from the community.The only problem I had with the game was the lack of bots, so if you just wanted a private match with a friend or two, the arena would feel very desolate. Other than that I felt the community could do better with a few thousand more players, so it would be easier to find games during different hours of the day.The asking price of 10 USD is fine, but if you find this under 1 USD during a sale, it would be a practical steal.

												I'd first like to point out that this is recommended, but only on a sale. It's not worth it otherwise.This game has a lot of potential. But it rarely does anything with it. The gameplay mechanics are great, online and local multiplayer is fun, the many different types of weapons provide many different ways to play, and once you get used to the unique movement mechanic, it's an amazing feeling to use gravity to zoom around different "planets". But the game just doesn't feel finished. It lacks things that I feel are basic to this type of game. It has no "normal" single player (which I'll expand on in a minute), no minimap of any kind, and really only 3 types of gamemodes. So, there is a type of single player, and it's not that bad. You just have to kill a certain amount of enemies in a certain amount of time, and unlock weapons as you go. But the annoying part is, this is the only type of single player. There's not any mod where you just pick a world and dificulty, put in bots, and just have a deathmatch. Yeah, there's that in multiplayer, but multiplayer has it's own problems. First off, it's hard to be a "noob" in mutiplayer. A good amount of these people have gotten pretty good and using the weapons, utilities, and maps fully to their advantage. Not to mention, the community is tiny. For the whole US, there's usually only one game going on at once. Only one. With maybe 8 people. Not a huge community. Yeah, multiplayer is fun, but since it's so small, they should add more gamemodes for single player.Gamemodes are another thing. There are only three. One for single player, and two for multiplayer. I personally would love seeing modes like survival, juggernaut, etc. Now, as you can see, I am recommending this. That's because, with all this missing, it's still a good game. At least, it has it's moments. When you're playing locally with a friend, it's a great small game to have. And, like I said, the gameplay mechanics are pretty good. It just feels more like an early access game than a finished game.So, overall, it's not a great game, but it's a good game. It can be fun to play sometimes, and it's a good game to mess around with friends. However, it feels like it's missing simple, easy-to-add things that would make it a far better game. So, feel free to get it, I'd just recommend getting it during a sale of some kind.

content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Just plain and simple, this isn't a particularly fun game as far as I'm concerned.  The concept is great; mechs in some sort of 2D space-theme shoot-em-up with massive stellar bodies and varying gravity, but throwing in non-optional and timed "orbital trials" just to unlock weaponry is annoying...The Best:- High quality backgrounds, backdrops, and environments (sort of a must-have for any 2D platformer style games these days).  If the trials weren't timed, I'd probably appreciate these graphics even more...- Sky is the limit (or space) as far as "how good you can get" is concerned; get comfortable with how the gravity works, how to move around, and be able to switch weapons when needed, but reaction-timing and coordination are serious game changers.The Good:- not terrible digital/techno style soundtracks- challenging fast-paced gameplay- rather challenging movement (in order to complete trials in a timely manner or be reasonably competitive in multiplayer, you'll have to be able to sling-shot around stellar bodies to get to some locations)The Bad:- TIMED TRIALS: you HAVE to follow the progression to be able to unlock each subsequent weapon, regardless of preferences in playstyle- Hit boxes: time and again, thought you just hit that enemy?  Well, it sure as hell hit you.- Lots of different "Gravitational Bodies," but none of them labeled or any inkling of the effect they will have on your or your weapons.The Ugly:- At least on PC/Mac, the keyboard controls are very difficult to get comfortable with; you can hold down the left or right arrow key and start running around a planetary body, but go to jump off or use a thruster and the arrow key held down still dictates your direction (even if you've run around to the opposite side)- No apparent variation in the stats of the mechs to fit different playstyles (slow and tanky, bruiser, fast but weak, etc.)- Timed trials are exactly the same each time; no variation in enemy behavior asside from scripts relating to player position means all you really have to do is get familiar with the layout and weapon characteristics and play a level over and over until earning 3 stars.Overall:As far as controls are concerned, I'd like to atleast have the option to keep the player "upright" constantly, and rotate the screen as you move; otherwise my personal opinion is that you HAVE to have a controller with an 8-direction pad for the movement to ever really feel natural, and a monitor refresh of at least 120hz.  Otherwise, as many would agree, if you're looking for a fast-paced, intense, and dynamic 2D game, Orbital Gear is probably for you.  If you get irritated easily when gameplay isn't particularly intuitive and you don't care for timed-trials (like myself) then Orbital Gear isn't.  If you can get past the timed trials, the multiplayer can be a lot of fun, as long as there are enough people online...

Posted: November 28, 2014
												This game is both awesome and terrible, but one that everyone should buy. Allow me to explain:In Orbital gear, you are some sort of giant robot, walking the surface of suspiciously small worlds that are placed odly close together. Using gravity, you jump from world to world, and using a small assortment of devestating weapons you hunt down other mechs and turn them into spaceborn scrap. It's not a complex game plot-wise, to the point I'm not sure it even has an excuse plot, but that doesn't make it less fun. The gravity physics are a bit magnetic, a nescesary thing to make it so that the game is actually playable, but once you find out how to work around and against them, it's awesome. In one match, I was able to launch myself into orbit, got a gravitational boost from 3 planets, exploded an enemy with my flamer, and killed myself by launching myself out of bounds. It was awesome.Now for the part that makes it terrible: there are no players! I hovered arround for ages, just experimenting with the game physics and waiting for someone to join the server, and when one finally did, it was this ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ whose entire strategy boiled down to, "Hide and use the seaker missiles to do my work for me." Later I managed to get a game going with something like 6 people, and it was awesome, but that was the exception rather than the rule. Another complaint, one that wouldn't be so bad if not for the first problem, is that the single player mode sucks. I honestly didn't even know there was a single player mode at first until I clicked up the time trial option, and even then it's kind of a crappy game mode. If they had taken the time to create a single player mode that's just like the real game but with AI opponents I wouldn't have any complaints about this game, but instead it's so multiplayer focused that it can't stand up if nobody's online.Verdict: I love this game, and the only reason I could complain is not enough people love it for more to love it. Luckilly, it's on sale! So go buy it!

												Plays like an arena shooter (like Unreal Tournament or Quake), but in 2D and with interesting movement mechanics due to the gravity. Fast-paced fun. Highly recommended.However: there is basically nobody playing on the public servers... so if you buy this game, get the 4-pack and give copies to your friends. Otherwise you'll have nobody to play with. Since there is no single player mode and no bots, having opponents is a requirement.The game has two modes: a free-for-all deathmatch mode and a team mode based around capturing objectives. The deathmatch mode is fun and works well but the team mode feels incomplete. For example, there is no direct feedback when you hit a target with your weapon. It's also nearly impossible to find enough players to organize teams... so practically speaking, you'll only ever play the deathmatch mode with your own friends.

												Orbital Gear is one of the most legitimately fun games I have ever played. It is fun for the sake of being fun. I'm not even that good, and yet, I still am laughing and having a blast whenever I decide to play it. It's fast, frantic, and wonderfully competitive, while being as simplistic as possible at the same time. I highly recommend this game. Get some friends together, start a Skype chat, and play. And now, until June 1, it's available for just a $1!Pros- Even when running at maxed out settings, it runs ridiculously smooth. Plus it looks gorgeous and has a perfect, distinct style.- The controls, while at first are frustrating, quickly become very familiar.- The use of gravity as a main gameplay element was actually pretty well implemented. Not perfect by any means, but it works for a majority of stages in the game.- The variety of weapons and stages is great. Each stage and weapon feels distinct. Having a favorite pairing of weapons, and a utility (a sort of enhancement for the user's mech) and then proceeding to master that loadout, feels just like having a favorite Smash Bros. character.Cons- Having controller support as an option may in itself sound great, but using a controller for this game sucks. It just doesn't work.- There are a number of different mechs to choose from from within the game. They all look different, with a great retro 80s 90s vibe, but the mechs themselves are just cosmetic, and don't really change anything. Plus within the game, they appear super tiny, so that was pretty useless.- Lack of replayability. Everything is already unlocked in this game the second you turn it on. Weapons, mechs, stages, everything.Anyways though, these cons are very minor as a whole really, and don't in anyway hinder the amount of childlike fun with this game. 9/10

Because it is really in the multiplayer aspects this game shines. The weapon and map variety is also nice. So far all the levels seems fun and with great opportunities for frantic combat. The gameplay is excellent if you are looking for a fun and frantic little 2D shooter. Weapons: 7/10. The weapons are nicely varied and well balanced, i do however have some personal issues with the some weapons. Namely the Phase orb.  Sound: 6/10. The guns sound good, the music sounds good and the annoucer is not annoying. All in all, very good. Levels: 7/10. All the levels are small enough to put you close to the action while still allowing for breathing room. Looks: 8/10. Everything looks excellent. The background in the leves looks nice and fits with every level, pretty enough to catch your eye, inconspicuous enough to not be distracting. 												ONE SENTENCE REVIEW:Orbital Gear is a 2D side scrolling shooter that does nothing new to the genre, bringing only a bare-bones shooter with bland visuals.LONG REVIEW:Orbital Gear, at first glance, seems to be a cool 2D shooter. You jump from "planet" to "planet" while trying to aim at your enemies, with a handful of guns. That being said the actual game isn't all its cracked up to be. Playing Orbital Gear is like having a shiny present under your Christmas tree, only to find out that inside that present is an old dusty toy that you already given before. Nothing in Orbital Gear feels new or innovative as I was lead to believe with the description, screenshots, and a few gameplay videos I saw. To sum it up the main gameplay is a mixed between your standard sidescrolling shooter and Angry Birds Space. As you jump from "planet" to "planet" started to remind of the levels in Angry Birds Space, where once you fling the bird across the planet the gravity will be make you "slinghsot" to your target. Similarly to this game. You move around jumping from here and there shooting people left and right, while dodging bullets. Rinse and repeat. As this is the only thing you do in the game, at it gets stale pretty quick since there's only (a total of) 3 Modes in the game. One for Singleplayer and Two for Multiplayer. The singleplayer mode is basically a time trial where the goal is kill and get the stars before time runs out. Nothing special, gets boring quick. Now for the multiplayer portion of this game. There are 2 modes: Deathmatch and Orbital Warfare, Deathmatch is pretty simple, nothing new or groundbreaking. Orbital Warfare on the other hand is the best part of this game where you join a team to protect your home planet and destroy the other, by either collecting power cores and fully powering their Doomsday Weapon or attack head on. This is an interesting mode not only because its unique but also it plays to the strengths of the game. Sadly though I am not recommending this game (currently the game costs a dollar less since its on sale) because the game is sadly dead. And this is the sad reality of multiplayer games once the flames of popularity slowly die down, so does the game. At the time of this review the game contains several servers (namely: USA, EUR, JPN, ASIA), and sadly to say ONLY EUROPE HAS PEOPLE PLAYING. There are no servers available in the other countries EXCEPT EUROPE. And normally there are only two (at the time of this review) and most of the time its almost always Deathmatch, meaning you'll probably never get to play the fun Orbital Warfare since no one plays it. Now the graphics of this game looks good, on screenshots. Sadly though its not really that great, for one when you select your "mech" you can obviously tell that the game is made with the Unity engine, sadly though this game doesn't fully utilize the engine, since the game: Dead Trigger 2 looks a lot better. The games textures aren't really that good either. While In-game the mechs may look cool and stuff, but at mech select screen (which is barely a select screen, more on that later) they look ugly and dated. The design of the maps aren't also that good. Some maps look cool while others just look like carbon copies, with just a different background. Now I rarely talk about this but, I feel the need to say this: the UI sucks. From the moment you boot up the game, you're greeted with a menu that looked straight out of a poorly made early access game. Go into settings or the Multiplayer select screens and you're greeted with the bumper triggers of on XBOX 360 controller on the top left and right. This makes me wonder if this game was created for the XBOX 360 but was rejected on the indie store and instead brought here on Steam.And lastly let me talk about its price. I converted it from my currency. So I'm estimating around 5-10 USD. Now let me ask you this is this game really worth it? For 5-10 USD you get a game that's practically dead with dated graphics and bad UI. Do you really think this is worth your money? You can probably spend that money on better things or on a Steam Sale. On the end of the day, No. I do not recommend this game.

												I like this game, I really do.It has fun, silly weapons/support items that are situationally OP (depending on map) meaning you need to learn them all and understand when to switch to counter your opponents.Movement is a blast, getting flung around planets at increasingly high speeds and then landing on top of someone with a pulse rocket explosion is great.Visuals are simple but crisp, everything is low-poly but some excellent colour choice and parallax effects really sell it. Each stage is unique in both appearance and layout, every single one is worth experiencing. The mechs themselves look okay at best (very N64-steez), but that barely matters since you view them from such a zoomed out perspective.The sound effects are stellar, and the music is a fun, pumping, Tron-style track that matches the on-screen action to a T.It just has one huge problem: No one is playing it. The only time there is ever a server is when me and my friends go make one to play with 4 players.So fair warning; bring friends who you can hit up to play with you. You will almost never find active servers with more than 1 or 2 people in them, and even then the lag can be just agony.

												The good:It's like you're a tiny gundam fighting other tiny gundams. Seriously, when you're weaving through the planets in an epic duel with some other tiny robot this game is at its best. There are plenty of guns, equip items, and robots. If I'm in a lobby and suddenly there are two of us instead of eight, I'd like for bots to take their place. So that all being said, this game is really fun when it shines, and I have no *gameplay* issues with it. The gravity flying about thing is really fun. I follow the 1$=1hr rule, so pick this up while its on sale: I can't recommend it full price. If you have friends, consider the 4 pack (on sale, of course). 												The good:It's like you're a tiny gundam fighting other tiny gundams. Seriously, when you're weaving through the planets in an epic duel with some other tiny robot this game is at its best. There are plenty of guns, equip items, and robots. The bad:People only ever play the deathmatch gamemode from what I've seen, but that doesn't matter really, for reasons to be stated shortly.The time between games isn't long at all, and while there isn't much to do between games, I'd still like more than a ten second break, because once in game, it can take a while, especially with low player numbers, for someone to win. I suppose you could just not respawn for a bit or something, but that defeats the purpose and is beside the point. Because of that, I only ever play for 30 minutes at a time. The lack of bots isn't frustrating, not yet. A game destined to have a small playerbase like this needs them though. If I'm in a lobby and suddenly there are two of us instead of eight, I'd like for bots to take their place. So that all being said, this game is really fun when it shines, and I have no *gameplay* issues with it. The gravity flying about thing is really fun. I follow the 1$=1hr rule, so pick this up while its on sale: I can't recommend it full price. If you have friends, consider the 4 pack (on sale, of course). Four people is a good game in orbital gear, three is doable but that magical fourth makes it so much more fun.

												The good:It's like you're a tiny gundam fighting other tiny gundams. Seriously, when you're weaving through the planets in an epic duel with some other tiny robot this game is at its best. There are plenty of guns, equip items, and robots. The bad:People only ever play the deathmatch gamemode from what I've seen, but that doesn't matter really, for reasons to be stated shortly.The time between games isn't long at all, and while there isn't much to do between games, I'd still like more than a ten second break, because once in game, it can take a while, especially with low player numbers, for someone to win. I suppose you could just not respawn for a bit or something, but that defeats the purpose and is beside the point. Because of that, I only ever play for 30 minutes at a time. The lack of bots isn't frustrating, not yet. A game destined to have a small playerbase like this needs them though. If I'm in a lobby and suddenly there are two of us instead of eight, I'd like for bots to take their place. So that all being said, this game is really fun when it shines, and I have no *gameplay* issues with it. The gravity flying about thing is really fun. I follow the 1$=1hr rule, so pick this up while its on sale: I can't recommend it full price. If you have friends, consider the 4 pack (on sale, of course). Four people is a good game in orbital gear, three is doable but that magical fourth makes it so much more fun.
